Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_DESC: With production and costs pre-reported, the focus in Q2 was on progress at Lindero and Fortuna’s balance sheet. Lindero was 97% complete as of the end of June 2020 (as previously reported), and Fortuna expects to produce 25koz-28koz from the asset in Q4 before announcing commercial production in Q1/21, with $55M-$60M in preproduction expenses remaining. Positively, Fortuna used the proceeds from its $69M equity financing in Q2 to repay $55M on its revolving credit facility, alleviating near-term balance sheet stress surrounding the $30M repayment due by the end of 2020. Fortuna is well positioned for a better second half after a challenging H1/20, but the ramp-up risk at Lindero remains an overhang in the near term. As a result, we maintain our Neutral rating, but increase our price target from C$9 to C$10.
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE: Surprise-free Q2; Lindero First Pour Expected By End Of Q3
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE_TLTP: Surprise-free Q2; Lindero First Pour Expected By End Of Q3

Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_DESC:
Morning Macro Trading Comment
Gold is slightly weaker and the USD is steady this morning, as bond yields rise and after lacklustre economic data came out of China. Base metal prices, however, are all stronger on the data. Copper is up 0.95% at US$2.88/lb, Nickel is up 2.05% at US$6.46/lb, Zinc is up 0.85% at US$1.07/lb and Lead is up 0.65% at US$0.88/lb. As the number of second wave cases rise across continental Europe, the British government extended its 14-day quarantine measure to now include arrivals from France, the Netherlands, Monaco, Malta, Turks and Caicos and Aruba. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has extended the lockdown in Auckland for a further 12 days in an attempt to stamp out the first outbreak of COVID-19 in four months. There’s little chance of agreement on a new federal coronavirus relief plan without a compromise on the roughly US$1T in aid. Democrats have offered to cut their original stimulus proposal of US$3.5 trillion by roughly one-third, but insist on keeping help for states, cities and other municipalities. For data today, U.S. retail sales rose only 1.2% M/M vs. expectations of 2.1%. Though growth was slower than the previous two months, sales are now back at February’s level. Later in the morning, industrial production (9:15 a.m.) and Michigan Sentiment (10:00 a.m.). China’s retail sales in July fell short of expectations, putting a dent in the recovery of the world’s second largest economy. The data showed a fall of 1.1% Y/Y. Industrial production was also below expectations (+4.8% Y/Y). Short-term trading sell targets are ~$1,961/oz in gold and ~$26.92/oz in silver.  

Snapshots
NCM – Earnings In Line, Weaker 2021 Guidance Than Expected, H2/20 Dividend Increased
FVI – Mixed Q2 Financials; Debt Reduced As Lindero Progresses
OLA – Orla Receives Final Camino Rojo Permit.
LGO – Q2 As Expected.
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_ANALYST_FULL_NAME: Anita Soni, Oscar Cabrera, Cosmos Chiu, Bryce Adams

Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_DESC:
Largo reported Q2/20 EPS of ($0.01), in line with our estimate and consensus of ($0.01). EBITDA of ($3.3M) came in ahead of our ($4.9M) estimate, driven by higher sales and better-than-expected cost results.
Overall, an in-line quarter and we expect a limited market impact on Q2/20 numbers. However, going forward we expect the stock to rerate as the company takes advantage of its commercial independence, with a focus on attracting a price premium for its high-purity vanadium product. We maintain our Outperformer rating but reduce our price target to C$2.20 (from C$2.50) after model updates and changing reporting currency to USD, from CAD.
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE: As Expected, Reduced Sales Impact Q2 Results
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE_TLTP: As Expected, Reduced Sales Impact Q2 Results

Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_DESC:
Canopy Rivers released its FQ1 results this morning. While reported EBITDA was slightly below our estimates, the far more relevant news was the company’s announcement of material financial uncertainty at PharmHouse, the company’s largest JV investment.
RIV announced it has formed a special committee to explore strategic alternatives for PharmHouse, including potentially adding more capital (either debt or equity), renegotiating existing offtake agreements, obtaining additional third-party financing, or potentially selling the company’s stake in the JV. RIV also stated that it has contributed additional capital to the JV, but did not disclose the amount. RIV’s net cash balance as at the end of the quarter was ~$44MM. 
It is difficult to predict with any remote certainty the outcome of the strategic alternatives process. It is possible the company could sell its stake for the value of the debt plus an incremental amount. We also believe it is possible that RIV could contribute sufficient capital (and take additional ownership) to allow PharmHouse to reach operating status to the point where it is able to cultivate and sell to its offtake partners, Canopy Growth and TerrAscend. Finally, RIV could renegotiate these offtake deals—which are substantially in RIV’s favour—with CGC and TER in exchange for either of those companies providing liquidity to PharmHouse. There is no clarity on the eventual outcome, but we believe investors will view this lack of certainty negatively, even though the current value of RIV stock is equal to its TER holdings plus net cash, implying no value for PharmHouse or any other equity investments.
Of critical importance now is the question of ownership of PharmHouse’s debt, which we estimate at ~$90MM of bank debt and ~$40MM owing to RIV. We expect this topic to be a significant area of focus on today’s call. The company will host a call at 9:00 a.m. ET; call-in number is 888-390-0546.

Our Conclusion
The quarter had puts and takes, that largely net out to it being an in-line print. However, the key takeaway was the company securing an amended borrowing agreement along with needed covenant relief. We believe this will ease a major overhang on the stock and de-risk the story meaningfully. Nonetheless we still anticipate a challenging operating environment moving forward given the combination of: 1) lackluster demand for new well completions; and 2) the oversupplied pressure pumping market. 
What’s The Event
STEP reported an in-line Q2/20 with an adjusted EBITDA loss of $3.5MM (includes a $3.1MM CEWS tailwind), which compared to us calling for a loss of $3.8MM and consensus a loss of $3.4MM. However the main news out of the quarter was STEP securing a renegotiated credit facility and covenant relief that adds needed breathing room. Segment updates and other highlights include:
Covenant relief secured: Post quarter-end STEP signed an amended borrowing agreement whereby: 1) the borrowing base is declining to $255MM Canadian and $15MM U.S. (from $323.3MM Canadian and $20MM U.S.); 2) additional borrowing restrictions are added; and 3) new covenant rules. On the latter, this includes the deferral of Funded Debt to EBITDA restrictions (<3x starting in Q3/21) and a reduction to the required Interest Coverage. Additionally, Funded Debt to tangible net worth cannot fall below 1.25x and there is a minimum quarterly EBITDA requirement (Q3/20: -$0.8MM, Q4/20: -$3.9MM, Q1/21: -$3.3MM and Q2/21:-$3.4MM). The June 2022 expiry of the facility remains unchanged and at quarter-end STEP had ~$203MM drawn on the facility.
Canada: WCSB activity came in meaningfully lower than expected as fracturing operations had only 14 operating days versus 255 in Q2/19. However, this was more than offset by better-than-expected margins as we were expecting a negative print. Activity is expected to rebound in Q3/20 with the company guiding to operate two to three fracturing crews and four to six coiled tubing units. 
U.S.:  Activity fell a touch below our expectations, however, softer margins led the segment to post weaker-than-expected results. Through the quarter the company operated one fracturing crew, which is expected to remain unchanged through the balance of the year. Both pressure pumping and coiled tubing operations witnessed significant pricing erosions and competitive pressures. STEP also realized a $13.1MM impairment to its U.S. fracturing platform.
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE: Q2/20 First Look: In-line Print; Covenant Relief Secured
Home_CIBC_Recent.REP_TITLE_TLTP: Q2/20 First Look: In-line Print; Covenant Relief Secured

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: AND’s Q2 results again highlighted that the company has a robust growth profile, wide competitive moat, and enviable marketing positioning. We have increased our estimates to reflect higher margins. Our price target increases from $37 to $40. We maintain our Neutral rating. While we have a positive outlook on AND’s fundamentals, our Neutral rating reflects its valuation, which is at the upper end of where specialty transportation names trade.

The turnaround story has been longer and more challenged than hoped, but underlying trends are positive, and the rest of the year sets up favourably. New and used vehicle sales are trending up strong double digits, lucrative Finance & Insurance per unit has taken a step up, and Parts, Service & Collision appears to be recovering. As importantly, net debt again improved materially and we no longer see the balance sheet as a concern; indeed, it appears to be in a good enough shape that M&A is again a possibility. Valuation and lack of visibility hold us back from getting too positive, but we acknowledge significant upside if the plan goes as pitched by ACQ. Our price target increases to $17 (from $9) and we upgrade AutoCanada to Neutral.

BSR reported an operationally in-line quarter, with occupancy and rental growth continuing to trend positively despite the ongoing pandemic. With operations largely under control, our focus turns to the REIT’s extensive capital recycling strategy, which is well under way. To this end, we note that multi-family transactions have continued at a solid pace, and management is not seeing cap rate expansion in its markets – these are positive indications that disposition/acquisition activity can be executed as planned. We believe that there is significant merit to the REITs strategy, in that it will ultimately be accretive to FFO/NAV over the longer term (despite temporary short-term dilution).  
We reiterate our Outperformer thesis; we believe that favourable fundamentals in the U.S. "Sun Belt" region should lead to above-average top-line growth over the long term, while valuation levels have significant scope for further expansion (on both an absolute and relative basis). We increase our price target to $12.25 (from $12.00), which is based on parity to our $12.25 NAV estimate (also increased from $12.00).
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE: A Sunny (Belt) Outlook Despite All The...
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: A Sunny (Belt) Outlook Despite All The Noise

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: BAM’s record fundraising activity, through a period of arguably unparalleled uncertainty, speaks to the strength, and indeed growth potential, of the asset management platform. While management has been patient in terms of capital deployment to date, we believe that the investment opportunities offered within the current market environment fit squarely within the wheelhouse of BAM’s contrarian, and value-add, investment strategy. We re-affirm our thesis, in that AUM growth (underpinned by an acceleration in real asset allocations) should drive above-average NAV growth, and believe that current share prices represent a compelling entry point for investors. Our FFO estimates are updated to reflect the results in the quarter (we include gains in our estimates), but we maintain our $44.00 price target, which is derived by applying a slight premium to our unchanged conservative $40.00 NAV.

CHR reported better-than-expected Q2 results and provided an update on its operations that should help ease investors’ fears over its counterparty risk. While we are not suggesting that counterparty risk has been eliminated, we do believe that the market has been overly punitive. We maintain our Outperformer rating and $4.25 price target.

Our take on EIF’s Q2/20 results is positive. Adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS were both beats. On a segment basis, performance was pretty much as expected: manufacturing was a bright spot, offset by weaker Aerospace & Aviation. The outlook is optimistic, outside of Regional One, supported by recent developments. Further, our take is EIF will take an appropriately prudent approach to capex and acquisitions. We are bumping up our estimates and our price target from $30.00 to $35.50. We missed the stock’s recovery from the early COVID-19 pandemic sell-off, but are wary of current stock market levels in light of new-case persistence. Thus, we maintain our Neutral rating, looking for a better entry point.

We are dropping coverage of Freshii, effective August 13, 2020, due to a re-alignment of the analyst’s coverage universe. Effective with this note, our prior rating, estimates and price target should not be relied upon going forward.

While GFL was viewed as the most likely candidate to acquire WM’s divestiture package and WCA, the announcement of both acquisitions less than two months apart is likely faster than most were expecting. That said, it does not take away from the complementary nature of the WCA acquisition with GFL’s existing footprint, especially in conjunction with WM assets. While we acknowledge the pushbacks we hear on GFL (higher leverage ratio, aggressive acquisition strategy), we see a compelling risk/reward set-up given the earnings/FCF potential and valuation upside. We have not adjusted our estimates for the WCA deal. We maintain our Outperformer rating and $32 price target.
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Expanding U.S Footprint With Acquisition Of WCA

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC:
H&R delivered an operationally in-line quarter, with strength (industrial + residential) and weakness (the retail portfolio) exactly where one would expect it. Rent collection is trending positively, especially with respect to enclosed malls – the segment of the portfolio which has been most materially impacted by the pandemic (and we suspect is having a disproportionate  impact on the REIT’s unit value). While we acknowledge that H&R may continue to face a challenging environment through H2/20, we expect a slow and steady recovery in operating metrics through 2021, and note that the REIT’s significant $1.1B+ liquidity provides a more-than-adequate (excessive?) safety net should fundamental conditions worsen. Our Outperformer rating remains rooted in the REIT’s deep discount to NAV (which we believe implies a deterioration in the underlying value of the real estate well beyond what is likely to or has transpired). 
Our 2020 and 2021 FFO estimates decline slightly, reflecting the results of the quarter. However, we maintain our $16.00 price target, which we derive by applying a 20% discount to our unchanged $20.00 NAV.

ITP reported good Q2/20 results, showing a modest beat despite the effects of the pandemic. Guidance remains withdrawn – a prudent approach, given economic uncertainty and the persistence of new COVID-19 cases. Still, there were bright spots, particularly products used throughout e-commerce channels, and management believes trends are improving for more traditional products, e.g., industrial tapes, film carton sealing tapes and film products. We have nudged up our estimates and are raising our price target from $13.50 to $16.00 as we increase our valuation multiple. Our rating remains Neutral.
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Q2/20 Wrap-up: Solid Quarter, Raising Price Target

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: The company faced a challenging quarter in the midst of the pandemic, as did the entire seniors housing sector at large, and continued pressure is expected to weigh on occupancy and operator cashflow stability in coming quarters. Potential near-term road bumps exist in lease restructuring discussions with Symcare (~44% of seniors housing triple net rental revenues) and Bridgemoor as well as providing COVID-19 relief and possible outcomes include swapping in a new operating team, property sales, as well as rent reductions. While skilled nursing operators have received government funding relief under CARES, help for seniors housing operators remains to be seen. After model maintenance, our NAV is reduced to $4.25. We acknowledge that valuation is attractive, but in light of the company’s relatively high leverage and uncertainties in the operating environment including the potential for rent reductions and an operator transition, we maintain our Neutral rating and reduce our price target to $3.75.
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Q2/20 Earnings: Environment Continues To Evolve

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: Another strong quarter from Jamieson showed constructive underlying revenue trends that bode well for both near- and longer-term prospects. While growth earlier this year was boosted by panic buying, JWEL is now seeing consistently higher consumption across categories, new customers, and market share gains in store and online. International growth continues to outperform on more than just China, though China is progressing impressively and is a massive opportunity. Our price target increases from $36 to $42 on a higher multiple; our rating remains Outperformer.

Blowout Q2 earnings were impressive and suggest more limited downside than feared due to cost flexibility, a scalable online platform, and exposure to many of the spend-on-the-home categories that are taking a larger share of discretionary spending. While momentum is strong and we are raising our estimates, we are cautious on sales later in the year and the effect on profitability when stores are fully open and the workforce is fully employed. Our price target increases to $17 (from $14) and our rating remains Neutral.

While NPI’s valuation has expanded, and there might be less upside relative to historical multiples and conventional NAV valuation approaches, we still view NPI as one of best positioned and a preferred name in the renewable IPP sector. We believe it can create more upside from its differentiated offshore wind development platform, with some complementary growth from onshore and other infrastructure assets. We expect continued development success over coming quarters and the funding outlook remains solid. We reiterate our Outperformer rating and our target increases to $38 (was $36).
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.INDUSTRY_NAME: Independent Power and Renewable Electricity Producers
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Development Strengths Boosted By Sector Tailwinds

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: With no current outbreaks at any of the company’s homes as of August 11, and properties re-opened for tours and move-ins, we expect occupancy to eventually stabilize in the coming months as the pipeline of pent-up needs-based demand is addressed. Resident deposits have been noted by management to be materially higher over the past several weeks and we expect the company’s new policies around hiring, pandemic control, and PPE capacity to provide a lasting benefit to the company, especially if there is a second wave. We believe SIA provides an essential service and has been a valuable partner to the long-term care sector and on government initiatives in its 46-year operating history. Net pandemic-related expenses likely peaked in Q2; however, an above-average expense rate is expected to persist through year end. While it is still too early for an “all-clear” signal, the largest COVID-19-related challenges could be in the rear-view mirror. SIA trades at a compelling valuation (~35% discount to our revised $16.50 NAV), which we think could ultimately close with alleviating headline risk and long-term demographic tailwinds. We maintain our Outperformer rating.
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE: Q2/20 Wrap-up: Zero Case Milestone Ach...
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Q2/20 Wrap-up: Zero Case Milestone Achieved

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: Storm posted a solid update, led by stronger-than-expected cash flows this quarter, as the completion of the Nig gas plant in late February drove down operating costs and increased liquids yields. While we had already assumed a weak Q3 due to McMahon outages, Street assumptions remain too high at this point, and could be a slight drag on the shares over the interim. Even so, we continue to like the set-up for this company as it heads into 2021, with Storm now on the other side of a multi-year infrastructure build at Nig. Capital efficiencies should therefore markedly improve over 2019 levels, and Nig offers superior productivity and cost structure advantages that were on display this quarter. Due to the improvement in strip pricing since our last update, we are increasing our price target to $2.75 (from $2.50). Although the market remains focused on larger capitalized entities, we continue to see Storm as a high-quality small-cap stock that is too cheap to ignore at these levels. On our revised estimates, the stock trades at 2.8x 2021E EV/DACF on strip (peers at 3.9x), carries an FCF yield of 13% (peers at 11%), and has a strong balance sheet (1.0x D/CF versus peers at 2.6x).
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE: Q2/20 Recap: Headwinds Shifting To Tai...
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Q2/20 Recap: Headwinds Shifting To Tailwinds As Nig Arrives

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: Post SPB’s strong Q2/20 results, we are raising our price target to $14.50 from $13.50 and remain Outperformer rated. After actualizing the solid Q2/20 results and tweaking H2/20 estimates slightly lower to reflect a more cautious Specialty Chemicals outlook (note, we had already accounted for narrowing propane margins in H2/20), our 2020 EBITDA estimate increases to $490MM or roughly $15MM higher than SPB’s guidance (i.e., low-end of $475MM-$515MM range). Our 2021 estimate increases to $520MM, reflecting more tuck-in M&A and a leaner cost structure post the restructuring undertaken this year. We continue to like the relative stability of SPB’s Energy Distribution platform (~75% of EBITDA) and better balance sheet position post the completion of the Brookfield investment.

The company is making incremental operating improvements and industry conditions have improved since the trough, but we continue to use a conservative valuation in light of the company’s leverage. We reiterate our Neutral rating and $0.90, EV/EBITDA multiple-based price target.
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Q2/20 Results: Improving Operations, But Leverage Elevated

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC:
Random Lengths reported that W. SPF benchmark lumber prices increased by 12.1% or $82 W/W to a record-high of $760/mfbm ($33 higher than midweek). In the South, SYP 2x4 prices rose 11.9% or $76 W/W to $716/mfbm ($31 higher than midweek), while the SYP Composite rose 9.5% or $66 to $762/mfbm. Over the past 19 weeks, SPF prices have risen 170% while the SYP 2x4 benchmark is up 127%. While current prices are hitting new peaks in nominal terms, we note that they are still 2% lower than the all-time peak that occurred over 23 years ago on November 8, 1996 when the-then ‘Std&Btr 2x4’ benchmark hit $480/mfbm (~$775/mfbm in today's dollars after adjusting for inflation).
The trade magazine pointed to continued momentum across markets as levels increased by double-digits. Some buyers contemplated stepping away from the market, voicing downside risk concerns, but current sales activity did not allow for it. Buyers remained frustrated with their inability to cover immediate needs. In W. SPF, prices rose by $60-$100 across the board, with 2x4 quotes reaching as high as $790 as order files stretched into early October. Some industrial buyers of low grade pulled back citing an inability to pass on current prices to customers. In SYP, prices surged further into record territory as order files reportedly extended into mid-September, with robust demand and mill output disrupted by COVID staffing challenges. Despite the sharp increases, homebuilders and other end users had to buy wood. Treaters (R&R) reported order files as far out as eight weeks.
Mortgage Rates Up W/W On GSE Fee Shock: Freddie Mac reported that the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage survey averaged 2.96% earlier this week, up from 2.88% a week ago but much lower than the 3.60% level a year ago. Mortgage News Daily (more current) pegs rates to be 3.08% as rates were negatively affected by increased Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac regulatory costs (which lenders are now passing on to consumers). Housing Wire estimates the new Market Condition Credit Fee (0.5%), effective September 1, will cost an average homeowner refinancing their mortgage approximately $1,400. 
Mercer Offers Stalking Horse Bid For Klausner Mill In Florida: According to Bloomberg, Mercer has offered a $26MM stalking horse bid for the indefinitely curtailed Klausner Lumber One mill in Live Oak, FL (~200 mmfbm/yr on two shifts) as part of the Austrian company’s bankruptcy court proceedings in Delaware. We view this potential acquisition positively for Mercer as the company has a proven ability to operate the unique European technology (Linck) Klausner installed, and MERC should be able to solve the wood supply challenges Klausner faced (which we understand stemmed from irregular payments to suppliers not a lack of fiber availability).
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE: Lumber Rising; Mercer Coming To Florida?
Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_TITLE_TOOLTIP: Lumber Rising; Mercer Coming To Florida?

Home_CIBC_StreetSmarts.REP_DESC: A rapid acceleration in the adoption and popularity of online spending and e-commerce has been one of the major themes of the pandemic economy. Shoppers have overwhelmingly turned to online stores and ordering to reduce their risk of exposure to the coronavirus. Retailers have responded in kind, accelerating digital transformations and purchasing digital enablement technology to help meet the unprecedented spike in demand. A recent report from Adobe gathered data from one trillion visits to retail sites and over 100 million SKUs using its Adobe Analytics software and Adobe Sensei Artificial Intelligence. The report gives us an insight into the extent of the increase in online sales with real-time data from July showing a 56% Y/Y increase in online sales. The reopening of physical stores in July did slow the shift from a 76% Y/Y increase in June, but online spend in 2020 is still expected to exceed 2019 levels as early as October 5.

Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_DESC:
The pandemic is barely three months old but has already forced an unprecedented pace of change as consumers and the companies that serve them have rapidly adapted to new restrictions, perspectives and opportunities. It is unclear how sticky these changes are and which will permanently alter the landscape, but we do believe they will materially influence behaviour for at least the next year.
Most importantly, the unique changes seen by various demographics highlight the necessity of knowing your customer, and favour companies with the best insights and ability to execute in adapting their businesses to meet consumers’ shifting needs. Overall, we do not believe most companies in our coverage universe will see impairment to assets, but all will be required to adapt faster than at any time in their existence, which brings elevated risk.
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_ANALYST_FULL_NAME: Mark Petrie, John Zamparo, Matt Bank

Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_DESC:
There are opportunities to use quantitatively based approaches to drive outperformance in the real estate space. While only having its own GICS category for less than four years, REIT fundamentals have always been unique so quant analysis needs to be tailored to the sector. 
Our analysis suggests growth in Net Asset Value, Funds From Operations, and Dividend are powerful metrics. In addition, the sector is very sensitive to Momentum, while Yield is an inverse factor.
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_ANALYST_FULL_NAME: Ian de Verteuil, Chris Couprie, Dean Wilkinson, Sumayya Syed

Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_TITLE: Every Portfolio Should Have Some Bling
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_DESC:
With Central Bank printing presses running at full steam, we retain a positive outlook for gold prices over the next several years. As the sector has increased in importance, generalist investors will find it increasingly difficult to avoid owning gold equities without running the risk of material underperformance relative to benchmarks. As such, a key question is how to increase exposure. 
In our opinion, the long-held strategy of sticking only with royalty/streaming companies has likely run its course. We recommend investors also own a basket of producers for higher free cash flow yield and leverage to the gold price.
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_ANALYST_FULL_NAME: Ian de Verteuil, Cosmos Chiu, Anita Soni, Bryce Adams

Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_TITLE: Shopify Fulfillment Network Could Be Transformational
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_DESC:
Shopify processes 5%-10% of all U.S. retail e-commerce sales and ranks as the third-largest platform in the industry behind Amazon and eBay. To build on its product offering, Shopify announced in June 2019 plans for the Shopify Fulfillment Network (SFN) to provide fast, reliable, and affordable fulfillment for its merchants in the form of two-day shipping. SFN is now available and ready for the early users. In this report we assess the unique opportunities SFN could deliver over the next five years.
While at this time, we exclude SFN from our price target calculation, SFN could prove transformative for Shopify if successfully implemented at the targeted spend rate and timeline. Once merchant take-up data is better known, we will include SFN in our forecasts. 
By our estimates, SFN could add up to $8 per share in 2020 and ~$60 by 2023, assuming modest adoption of 2.5% and 10% of total GMV by 2020 and 2023, respectively. We forecast that SFN adoption of 25% could add ~$143 per share by 2023. 
Despite the exclusion of SFN from our estimates at this time, we still increase our price target to $525 (from $350), now using our 2021 forecast and a forward P/S multiple of 20x. Our target multiple rises from 18x, reflecting an expansion in multiples for enterprise cloud peers.

Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_TITLE: Impact Of Climate Change And Extreme Weather On The Agriculture Industry
Home_CIBC_BTH.REP_DESC:
This year has been characterised by unprecedented rainfall and flooding in the U.S., severe drought conditions in Australia and strange monsoon patterns in India. These events seem to be of a higher frequency, begging the question of whether this is the new normal, and if so what does it mean for the global agriculture industry? In this report, we examine the historical data and projected models of extreme weather events and temperatures in key geographies, and arrive at possible conclusions for the global agricultural industry in terms of impacts on crop yields, regional production shifts, and logistics. Among the themes we discuss inside are:

1) Canadian Ag. Could Emerge A Winner; U.S. Outlook Mixed: Historical data suggests that Canada has had a relatively lower rate of extreme weather events. Looking ahead, the Canadian Prairies and the U.S. Dakotas will likely see improved yields with warming temperatures. Southern regions in the U.S. are likely to be impacted by drought. There is a rising trend of floods in the U.S., but U.S. agriculture should be less impacted than several other key global growing regions.

2) Promising Brazilian Ag. Outlook Could Face Challenges: Extreme weather events are on the rise in South America. The World Bank ranks Brazil as one of the key areas globally that could be most affected by climate change.

3) No Major Impact On Long-term Fertilizer Demand: Although demand can be significantly impacted by weather patterns (as over the past 12 months), several other factors are also at play (e.g., pricing). There is no clear trend to suggest that weather alone significantly affects fertilizer demand.

4) Pesticide Use Set To Increase: Climate change will increase the root-to-shoot ratio, reducing pesticide uptake and leading to higher pest/weed populations and yield declines.

We also discuss how climate changes strengthen the case for a revamp of global grain/food infrastructure and will likely rework transport routes. Less Mississippi River barge traffic will probably result in more rail/truck and other port utilization.

Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_TITLE: A New Product Offering For Investors
Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_DESC:
One of the wonderful elements of the investment business is its ability to change and evolve over time. Benchmarks change. Stocks go public. Companies are acquired. Trends go in and out of favor. Likewise, sell-side firms must evolve if they are to effectively serve investing clients.
It is in this vein we are pleased to announce our latest advancement. Where possible, we have incorporated a new scorecard within our security research. This tear sheet will show Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) metrics, as well as Quantitative and Technical scores based on proprietary CIBC Research. 
Regardless of an investor’s perspective, the reality is that the current capital markets environment sees investors of all stripes. The historically dominant fundamental investor group has witnessed the substantial growth of quantitative-oriented investors. Technical investing has been around for an extended period, and in the current environment it is certainly having another day in the sun. 
ESG has been in the ascendency over the past several years. Investors had always focused on governance issues, but as we have learnt in a world of climate change and social licences, the broader concept of sustainability has rightly become more relevant. To address this issue, we have partnered with Sustainalytics to provide a resource for both investors and issuers to understand the risks and opportunities related to ESG. 
There are two caveats we would mention. First, ESG is not an “on or off” switch; it means different things to different people. This requires ESG information and perspectives be an adjunct to other investment research to understand the risks and potential rewards associated with a security. Second, in the case of some companies (particularly smaller ones), there may be insufficient information to add value from one or more of these three lenses.

Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_TITLE: Surface Freight Transportation: Modal Shift As A Decarbonization Strategy
Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_DESC:
Although all forms of transportation generate some environmental impact, a vibrant Canadian economy requires movement of people and products. While emissions intensity is being reduced by each method of transportation, a real opportunity arises from an increased shift to trains for surface freight transportation. 
This argument has been made for some time – indeed, North America’s major railroads have argued for increased share of freight transportation, largely through a shift to intermodal shipping. What has changed recently is the increased focus on CO2 footprints by governments, corporates, investors and consumers alike – and this makes the shift more likely.

Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_TITLE: Climate Change And The Canadian Institutional Investor
Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_DESC:
When it comes to ESG topics, Canadian companies, and particularly Canadian energy companies, often feel as if the world is conspiring against them. Virtually all human activity results in harm to the environment but climate change activists focus overwhelmingly on fossil fuels producers. If misery loves company, then oil and gas companies will appreciate the increased onus being placed on Canada’s investment managers and asset owners in 2020 for more disclosure and action. 
Regulatory bodies, non-government organizations (NGOs) and individual investors are not simply focusing on public industrial companies which may be large GHG emitters. They are also pressuring professionals in the investment business to consider and disclose risks and opportunities arising from climate change within investment portfolios. If owners are under pressure to disclose more, it’s safe to say that managers of the actual companies within their portfolios will as well.

Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_TITLE: Impact Of Climate Change And Extreme Weather On The Agriculture Industry
Home_CIBC_ESG.REP_DESC:
This year has been characterised by unprecedented rainfall and flooding in the U.S., severe drought conditions in Australia and strange monsoon patterns in India. These events seem to be of a higher frequency, begging the question of whether this is the new normal, and if so what does it mean for the global agriculture industry? In this report, we examine the historical data and projected models of extreme weather events and temperatures in key geographies, and arrive at possible conclusions for the global agricultural industry in terms of impacts on crop yields, regional production shifts, and logistics. Among the themes we discuss inside are:

1) Canadian Ag. Could Emerge A Winner; U.S. Outlook Mixed: Historical data suggests that Canada has had a relatively lower rate of extreme weather events. Looking ahead, the Canadian Prairies and the U.S. Dakotas will likely see improved yields with warming temperatures. Southern regions in the U.S. are likely to be impacted by drought. There is a rising trend of floods in the U.S., but U.S. agriculture should be less impacted than several other key global growing regions.

2) Promising Brazilian Ag. Outlook Could Face Challenges: Extreme weather events are on the rise in South America. The World Bank ranks Brazil as one of the key areas globally that could be most affected by climate change.

3) No Major Impact On Long-term Fertilizer Demand: Although demand can be significantly impacted by weather patterns (as over the past 12 months), several other factors are also at play (e.g., pricing). There is no clear trend to suggest that weather alone significantly affects fertilizer demand.

4) Pesticide Use Set To Increase: Climate change will increase the root-to-shoot ratio, reducing pesticide uptake and leading to higher pest/weed populations and yield declines.

We also discuss how climate changes strengthen the case for a revamp of global grain/food infrastructure and will likely rework transport routes. Less Mississippi River barge traffic will probably result in more rail/truck and other port utilization.

The combustion of fossil fuels is the single largest source of GHG emissions and we are seeing more industries facing additional scrutiny over emissions. One industry attracting more attention is the airline sector, which contributes ~2% of global GHG emissions. In this report, we take a look at how Air Canada (AC) fares amongst global network carriers based on Scope 1 emissions. Based on our work, the airline had the lowest CO2 emissions per passenger kilometer and per revenue tonne mile (RTM) amongst our sample of global carriers. AC's improved efficiency is being driven by its re-fleeting strategy, longer stage length, and increasing aircraft density. Versus its peer group, AC scores well from both an environmental and valuation perspective.

Home_CIBC_Primers.REP_DESC: This report is our seventh annual primer on the Canadian banks, which we hope will serve as a valuable document for new investors and generalists who may have a passing interest in the sector, as well as a reference document for specialists (like us) who may occasionally need a memory aid for topics that do not get as much discussion during the quarterly reporting cycle.

This is the third edition of our P&C insurance primer (previously published June 2014 and June 2016). The primer covers the basic, and not so basic, financial and accounting concepts behind P&C insurance. We also provide a look into the Canadian market, including competition, product lines, regions and regulations. Our report also includes company summaries for the two P&C companies we cover - Intact and Fairfax.

There are three topics in focus with this edition of the primer:

1) Rising Repair Costs In Personal Auto: Personal auto margins have compressed as a result of the industry, including Intact, not pricing sufficiently for rising repair costs. Canadian rate increases have lagged those in the U.S. by a wide margin. The good news is that rates are starting to firm, but we'd like to see more evidence that increases could push into the mid- to high single-digit range. A rate firming cycle could be very positive for Intact, as it has been for PGR south of the border. This is how a headwind could potentially turn into a tailwind. 

2) The Evolution Of Online Competition: A number of established insurance companies have launched digital platforms in Canada in recent years, albeit with limited success to date. Significant investments in marketing will be required to drive digital traffic and it will likely take multiple years to achieve scale. It will be worth keeping an eye out for potential disrupters from outside the insurance industry, such as Amazon. Lemonade, a U.S. fintech, is making lots of noise in the U.S. insurance industry, but we wonder if it will ever have the marketing budget to truly compete. Increasing digitization of insurance seems inevitable. What is not clear is when and who will benefit. 

3) Specialty Lines In Canada: Intact is targeting growth in Canadian insurance specialty lines given higher market growth rates, attractive underwriting margins and a relatively low market share. Intact's growth objective implies annual premium growth in the range of 7%-12%, a realistic goal given market growth of approximately 6% per year and a market share of only 6%. The most obvious paths to growth include marine and newer business lines, such as cyber insurance. Market share gains may have to come largely at the expense of large global players and the expertise that OneBeacon provides may help in this regard.

The 60-year-old satellite industry is rapidly evolving, undergoing a period of change unprecedented in its history. The evolution has been driven by technology innovation (high-throughput satellites, digital payloads, space-infrastructure-servicing), lower launch costs (reusable rockets) and the miniaturization of satellites (LEO, MEO).

With excess capacity in the broadcast satellite services market, the focus has shifted from video to data/mobile communications. 60% of the earth’s population does not have access to high-speed internet and 1.6 billion people don’t have access to mobile networks. We believe satellite operators (including LEO) are now focused on the global internet and mobile data opportunity. 

We believe these trends will lead to fewer GEO satellites launched (normalized at mid-high teens), but at potentially higher price points (high-throughput satellites are larger and more complex). If funded, we believe that next-generation LEO and MEO constellations could drive significant growth in the near future, with the industry projecting order flow of more than 500 small satellites per year ($1.5 billion/year). The U.S. government is also placing more emphasis on smaller, commercial satellites (versus highly customized) that are affordable, resilient and persistent, with the opportunity worth $10 billion/year.
 
Our updated primer explores these industry trends and opportunities.

Later this year, Canada will embark on a massive economic and social experiment as cannabis consumption and distribution is legalized. A handful of U.S. jurisdictions have already made this transition, and various countries have significantly relaxed regulations, but there is still a great deal of uncertainty about what this all means.
Home_CIBC_Primers.REP_ANALYST_FULL_NAME: John Zamparo, Prakash Gowd, Mark Petrie

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This week on The Holler, I spoke with CIBC’s Todd Coupland, Managing Director and Technology Analyst, to discuss the rapid evolution of digitization and e-commerce in Canada thru the COVID-19 pandemic and the pivotal role of Shopify.   Take a listen.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: July 22, 2020 Helen Hayes & Todd Coupland

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: With the substantial decline in interest rates, the S&P/TSX offers an excellent after-tax alternative for yield investors who are prepared to take modest additional risk.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Introducing Canada?s Undercover High Yield Market

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: In this video we provide our latest thoughts on the agriculture and chemical markets, highlighting the impact of wet starts to North American planting and of trade war issues. We also offer an overview of our top picks: Nutrien Ltd., Ag Growth International Inc., and Methanex Corporation.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Helen Hayes & Jacob Bout_May 1, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: We discuss in this short video the changing outlook for capital allocation in the energy infrastructure sector based on fireside discussions we held with various company executives at our 2019 Whistler Conference.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Robert Catellier_January 30, 2019_v2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: We review the drivers of our bullish gold outlook: USD strength ending, global slowdown, central bank purchases and investment demand. We saw a significant level of investor interest in gold equities at our Whistler Conference this year. Corporates addressed asset sales and M&A in their presentations.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Giorgia Anton & Anita Soni_January 29, 2019_v2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Power & Utility analyst Mark Jarvi reflects on highlights from the 22nd Annual Whistler Conference. Macro themes, which were more a conversation topic last year, took a backseat to more industry and sector-specific themes this year. This podcast briefly outlines a few of those themes and highlights preferred names in the sector.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Mark Jarvi_January 30, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This was the first year our Whistler Conference included the cannabis industry. Some of the largest players in the space talked to us about what they see for the future, as well as what some of the traditional CPG businesses bring to the table beyond simply their balance sheets. We also look at valuation within the industry and note one particularly compelling name.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & John Zamparo_January 29, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: As we discuss in this video, the software and services companies presenting at our 2019 Whistler Conference noted a solid demand environment, with upside from acquisitions.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Stephanie Price_January 29, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This video podcast summarizes our takeaways from Aritzia's fireside chat at this year's Whistler Conference and the key reasons it is one of our top picks for 2019.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Mark Petrie_January 29, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: With gold starting this year on a strong note against a backdrop of increasing geopolitical and recessionary concerns, we review key themes for the royalty companies and intermediate producers in 2019. We also highlight our top picks in each group, and touch on what we expect will be a busy 12 months of M&A across the industry.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Cosmos Chiu_January 29, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: After a busy acquisition year in 2018, Park Lawn is well set up for further growth in the highly fragmented, defensive North American death care industry. Management's focus in 2019 will be on asset integration/optimization and small deals on the back of a strong balance sheet. Beyond, we expect larger transactions to fuel growth and margin expansion, supporting healthy share valuation and our Outperformer rating. We also briefly discuss the investment outlooks for Alaris Royalty and Diversified Royalty.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Robert Sedran & Scott Fromson_January 29, 2019

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The investment community spends a tremendous amount of time on quarterly surprises. This podcast attempts to quantify the impact of ?beats and misses? and considers opportunities for investors.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Quantifying Conventional Wisdom

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Join Ian de Verteuil and Helen Hayes from CIBC for a broad-ranging discussion on the state of global trade against the backdrop of a protectionist White House. Topics include interest rates, equities, currencies and opportunities for 2019.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: The U.S.-China Trade War Is Evolving

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: We recently had the opportunity to spend a week exploring Brazilian agriculture and associated industries. This podcast summarizes the key investable themes that we discuss in our report, Brazil - The Global Agriculture Powerhouse.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Brazil - The Global Agriculture Powerhouse

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The combination of protectionism and US Tax Reform is a seminal event, which greatly increases the competitiveness of US business and will attract capital and activity into America for years to come.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: A Giant Sucking Sound: The Confluence Of Protectionism And US Tax Reform

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: In this episode we provide a brief overview of the Canadian office real estate sector, and go through some of the dynamics of the downtown and suburban markets. We have initiated coverage of two suburban office-focused REITs ? Slate Office REIT at Neutral with an $8.25 target and True North Commercial REIT at Neutral with a $6.50 target. We explore some of the salient points to these companies within this podcast.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Canadian Office Overview And Outlook

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The S&P/TSX had a reasonable year in 2017. We believe that 2018 will be trickier with risks from interest rates and possible trade disruptions. US tax reform probably will help US equities more and, outside of a spike in energy prices, the S&P500 should again beat the S&P/TSX.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Equity Outlook: Canada Will Have A More Difficult 2018

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Overview of strong Canadian industrial real estate fundamentals and updates on Pure Industrial REIT, Dream Industrial REIT and Summit Industrial Income REIT.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Strong Fundamentals Intact: Canadian Industrial Real Estate Update

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: US tax reform is positive for most companies, and even some Canadian companies will be able to reduce their tax bill. The longer-term ramifications, however, are more concerning. Canada is losing some of its competitive advantage as US tax rates drop and as the US reduces regulatory hurdles.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Making America Tax Competitive Again

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This podcast and our report, In Blockchain We Trust, provide an overview of blockchain technology and potential applications.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: In Blockchain We Trust

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This podcast and our fall outlook report provide an update and Q3/17 preview for E&C and Heavy Equipment companies. We also discuss some of our top 10 industry themes that touch on several topics including valuations, infrastructure spend, NAFTA, architecture billings, M&A, FX, amongst others.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Top 10 Themes For E&C And Heavy Equipment

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This podcast and our fall outlook report looks as key themes in agriculture (U.S., Canada, China, South America), chemicals (methanol, pulp chemicals) and fertilizers (potash, nitrogen, phosphates). We also summarize potential hits, misses and key themes for Q3/17.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Fall 2017 Agriculture, Chemicals And Fertilizers Outlook

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: A brief podcast supporting our report on the Alt-A mortgage lenders, "Alt-A Mortgage Lenders Down, But Not Out", in which we outline our investment thesis on Outperformer-rated Equitable Group (EQB) and Neutral-rated Home Capital Group (HCG).
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Alt-A Mortgage Lenders Down, But Not Out

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: We look at the complex and misunderstood software for self-driving cars and robotics. We consider BlackBerry's next phase and its leverage to automotive software, including self-driving cars. We conclude that Blackberry's leverage to autonomous driving has yet to be confirmed with QNX design wins. Confirmation of QNX's offerings is needed, in our view, to unlock value and/or to attract M&A interest. Our view is investors should not buy the stock for exposure to self-driving technology until we see a material win in this highly competitive and fragmented market.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Self-driving At Blackberry And Beyond

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Cyber-risk is one of those known unknown risks that PMs face - they know companies within their portfolios are vulnerable to cyber-attack but they don't know how to evaluate the risk. This report provides a simple starting point to allow investors to better engage with C-suite executives on this topic.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: The Known Unknown

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: A brief 5 minute podcast accompanying our launch of coverage report on the alternative fund managers, "Winter Is Coming! Flee To Alternative Fund Managers". In this podcast we outline our positive view on the alternative fund managers and the factors underpinning our Outperformer ratings on the shares of Fiera Capital and Gluskin Sheff.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Winter Is Coming! Time To Flee To Alternative Fund Managers

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Bank ROEs, important for both offence and defence, have been under near-constant pressure since the global financial crisis. We think the power of the factors that have caused these declines is beginning to fade, which suggests a better outlook than we have seen in some time and the possibility of even modest increases in operating ROE. This has positive implications to growth and the risk-reward profile of the sector. Moreover, we believe even stable ROEs should help with multiple expansion given valuations relative to international banks.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: ROE - What's Past Is Prologue

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Artificial Intelligence. Once considered pure science fiction, this technology is increasingly becoming reality. This podcast offers a brief look at recent AI trends and the emerging opportunity for technology firms.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Rage Against The (AI) Machine

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: On Friday June 9, CIBC held its ESG Conference in Toronto. Given attendance from issuers and investors, it is clear that this topic is becoming an increasingly important one in capital markets.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Ian de Verteuil_June 12, 2017

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Canadian public companies have made progress on increasing female representation on Boards of Directors, but more needs to be done.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Women On Public Company Boards In Canada

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Following the recent transfer of coverage of eight TSX-listed Canadian independent power producer (IPP) companies, Mark Jarvi provides a brief recap of how the sector has performed, highlighting key performance drivers, summarizes his outlook for the sector and discusses his top pick, Algonquin Power & Utilities.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Updated Outlook On The CanadianPower Sector

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: CIBC Capital Markets held its fifth Annual Technology & Innovation Conference in Toronto on May 16. CIBC industry experts Stephanie Price, Todd Coupland and Prakash Gowd give a short update on the conference and what to expect in this space in the future.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: @CMXchange – Tech & Innovation Conference 5.0 Wrap-up

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Two steps Forward, One Step Back - A 35 year bull market in Bonds doesn’t end Quickly. We discuss portfolio implications of a bottoming in long-term interest rates.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: A 35-Year Bull Market In Bonds Doesn't End Easily

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Uncertain US economic & fiscal policy continues to be front of mind for investors, while in Canada problems have arisen in the alternative mortgage market. In this video, we provide perspectives on managing equity portfolios in this volatile environment.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Ian.de Verteuil & Robert Sedran_v2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: A summary of our two-part Beyond the Headlines series analyzing Shopify’s growth prospects to support our positive investment thesis.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Deconstructing Shopify’s Growth

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: In this podcast, we take a look at a potential timeline for NAFTA renegotiations. In our view, the negotiation process will probably take 12 months, with formal discussions unlikely to commence until May. In the interim, expect continued uncertainty for the S&P/TSX Index and select Canadian companies due to the lack of clarity on U.S. “Asks” of NAFTA, but also from potential U.S. Tax Reform. So get comfortable – this will probably take a year.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 146380-Master-2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: In this podcast, we look back at trade policy during the Reagan administration as a case study for the current environment. In our view, we believe the Reagan years provide a possible playbook for the Trump administration in upcoming NAFTA renegotiations, and highlight the implications on Canadian equities.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 146183-Master-2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Portfolios Managers are under increased pressure to effectively deal with the risks in their portfolios as a result of Carbon and Climate change. The CIBC Carbon Portfolio Tracker is a useful tool to both manage and communicate exposures within Canadian portfolios.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 146129-Master-3

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This podcast highlights the key issues likely to impact the healthcare sector in 2017, and reasons for optimism.  It also reviews our three top Canadian healthcare picks.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Gowd170113

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: This Beyond The Headlines report, in collaboration with Transportation analyst Kevin Chiang, takes a deeper look at the relationship between Aimia and Air Canada. The report looks at the history of the relationship, the benefits to each party, and potential changes to the relationship as the expiry of their existing contract in 2020 nears.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 146005-Master-6

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: As a new calendar year begins, we take the opportunity to introduce the three key themes we think bank investors should be thinking about in 2017.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Sedran170111

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The outlook for the S&P/TSX for the next 12 months is much less sanguine than it was a year ago. While the price of WTI will be an important variable, the reality is that anti-trade forces will create material uncertainty for 2017. We expect modest equity returns, with the S&P500 outperforming the Canadian benchmark.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: All Eyes On Trump As We Enter The New Year

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Discounting 2017 auto sales. This Beyond The Headlines report, in collaboration with Strategist Ian de Verteuil, considers the impact of rising rates, Trump trade and next-generation technology.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 145745-Master-8

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Silver could outperform gold in 2017, with industrial demand shining through. CIBC’s top pick is PAAS.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Chiu161213

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The good news is that the strong performance of the S&P/TSX means that domestic fund managers will produce strong absolute returns for Canadian unit holders. Relative to common benchmarks however, performance will be less sanguine.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Strong Absolute Performance But Relative Headwinds For Mutual Funds

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Initiating coverage of Alaris Royalty (AD: Sector Outperformer, $24 price target) and Diversified Royalty (DIV: Sector Outperformer-Speculative, $3 price target). Different business models, but catalysts are key to both investment theses. Alaris Royalty: increased cash flow from turning around challenged investment partners. Diversified Royalty: royalty acquisitions to backfill the dividend.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Initiating_On_Two_Business_Royalty_Names

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Strong US economic growth, higher inflation and expansionary policy under President-Elect Trump suggest an extended period of US dollar strength. This report provides a tool for Canadian portfolio managers to monitor their currency exposure, and leverage Canadian companies with a notable US presence.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 145382-Master-2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: With the surprise election of Donald Trump, Markets will remain unsettled.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: de Verteuil161109

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: With little clarity on the U.S. Election, we should ponder various outcomes. In the final analysis though, it may not matter that much!
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 144970-Master-2

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Fall Fiscal Update by the Canadian federal government suggests that there will be additional tailwinds for Canada’s engineering and construction companies.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: Fiscal Update Provides Additional Tailwinds For E&C Stocks

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: It is clear that the risks to companies that emit large amounts of Greenhouse Gases (GHGs) is rising. We believe that our CIBC Carbon Portfolio Tracker offers investors a relatively simple way to evaluate this risk in their portfolios, in relation to broad market indices.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: de Verteuil161011

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Our investment thesis from our recent initiation report is based on the growing e-commerce market opportunity, Shopify’s competitive position, and the results from the CIBC Online store project. Combined, they support the company continuing to outperform expectations.
Home_CIBC_Podcasts.title: 144354-Master-7

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: The environment is becoming more difficult and risky for companies with comparatively low-rate rates – no matter the underlying reason for the tax rates. Investors need to be aware of this in an environment in which the rules and regulations are changing.

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Investing is both an absolute and relative game. This report focusses on the latter, with our periodic update on how Canadian Mutual Funds are positioned at the end of the second quarter.

Home_CIBC_Podcasts.description: Lobster used to be called the "cockroach of the sea," but those days are long gone. Nova Scotia lobster is now turned into frittatas topped with caviar that sell for $2,000 in New York City restaurants and packed into special crates to be flown live to Hong Kong.Canadian lobster catches in recent years have been called the best in a century. Crews in million-dollar boats are setting traps 50 kilometres off the coast. In 2015, Nova Scotia fishermen hauled in more than 49,000 tonnes of lobster worth nearly $700 million.But the flow of money hardly stops there. Dealers buy it off the dock and each lobster will likely pass through the hands of several middlemen before it finally reaches a grocery store tank or restaurant kitchen.Each sale means a markup. Last year, the value of lobster exports from Nova Scotia was nearly $1 billion.
